Subject: Between ages 65 and 80 ask your provider about an ultrasound to detect an AAA
General Patient Text: Your provider may ask for an ultrasound of your belly to detect a bulge in the main blood vessel (the bulge is nicknamed AAA for short or Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm) If the bulge grows it can burst and cause death.Reference: https://canadiantaskforce.ca/guidelines/published-guidelines/abdominal-aortic-aneurysm/

Subject: Screening for AAA in trans and non binary patients
General Patient Text: n/a
Health Provider Text: At this time we could not find a Canadian reference on this topic. In the UK trans females and non binary patients who were assigned male sex at birth are advised to have an abdominal ultrasound to detect AAA between ages 65 and 80. Trans males can have a screening ultrasound if they wish but the risk of an aneurysm is mentioned as being less. Reference: https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/nhs-population-screening-information-for-transgender-people

Subject: Between 65 and 80 you may need a test
General Patient Text: Canadian guidelines on screening for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA: a bulge in the main blood vessel of the body that can be dangerous) in trans and non binary people were not found. In the UK the following is recommended: If you are a trans female or non binary with sex assigned at birth as male you are advised to have an ultrasound to detect an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Speak to your provider about this. Currently trans males, and those who are non binary with sex assigned at birth as female, may not be advised to have this test. Research may change in this area. Speak to your health care provider.
Health Provider Text: n/a

General Patient Text: Physical activity prevents heart disease, cancer, depression and more. See this great Reference: https://www.reframehealthlab.com/23-and-12-hours/ . For more info see this Reference: https://www.nhs.uk/live-well/exercise/

Subject: Recommended physical activity
General Patient Text: The recommended minimum amount of physical activity is: 150 minutes a week of moderate intensity exercise and muscle strengthening 2 times a week. Definition of moderate intensity: while you are active you have enough breath to say a short sentence but not enough to sing. Subject: Information
General Patient Text: Physical exercise and a healthy diet keep your bones strong and prevent Osteoporosis.Some providers (Rainbow Health Ontario) recommend that all patients on hormone therapy ensure a daily intake of 1200 mg of calcium (diet + supplementation) and 1000 IU of vitamin D. More information on calcium and vitamin D, Reference: https://osteoporosis.ca/nutrition/, Bone density testing is recommended by Osteoporosis Canada for all genders at age 70. Medical reference, Reference: https://www.cmaj.ca/content/cmaj/195/39/E1333.full.pdf . The Canadian Task Force on Preventive Health Care recommends using this calculator, Reference: https://frax.canadiantaskforce.ca/, but some recommend combining male and female scores depending on the length of hormone treatment. Speak to your provider. You may need bone density testing earlier if: you had an orchiectomy (removal of the testes) or you are/were on a testosterone or puberty blocker (such as spironolactone, cyproterone or Lupron), and you were taking no/low doses of hormone therapy.You may also need testing earlier if you have other risk factors, Reference: https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/chronic-diseases/osteoporosis.html.These, are the same risk factors as for cisgender patients. Discuss any concerns you may have with your primary care provider. If you have been medically transitioning, consider using an average of both the female and male calculators to calculate your own fracture risk.
Health Provider Text: Bone density testing is recommended by Osteoporosis Canada 2023 guideline, Reference: https://www.cmaj.ca/content/cmaj/195/39/E1333.full.pdf, for all genders at age 70. The Canadian Task Force on Preventive Health Care recommends using this calculator, Reference: https://frax.canadiantaskforce.ca/, but some recommend combining male and female scores depending on the length of hormone treatment. None of these tools have been studied in trans and non binary populations. As per the current guidelines for the general population, screening with BMD should be considered for younger patients who have risk factors for osteoporosis, Reference: https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/chronic-diseases/osteoporosis.html, For trans women and people on the transfeminine spectrum, this also includes anyone who, regardless of age: 1) Has a history of hypogonadism/gonadectomy, and a history of insufficient (no/low-dose/intermittent) hormone replacement (UCSF recommends > 5 years without hormones to qualify; RHO recommends > 2 years; Endrocine Society, ISCD and TransCare BC do not specify a minimum amount of time). 2) A history of taking an anti-androgen/GnRH analogue without exogenous hormones (RHO, ISCD). 3) Is not adherent to hormone therapy or has taken it intermittently (Endocrine Society, TransCare BC) The RHO recommends that all patients on hormone therapy ensure a daily intake of 1200 mg of calcium and 1000 IU of vitamin D.

Subject: Information
General Patient Text: If you are taking estrogen and have breasts, you need regular screening mammograms depending on your age. The recommendation is for you to have a mammogram every 2 years from age 50 to 74. Some primary care providers may recommend that you only start undergoing mammograms at age 50 if you have been on estrogen for at least 5 years.
Health Provider Text: Trans women and people on the transfeminine spectrum who are on feminizing hormone therapy should undergo breast cancer screening as per current guidelines for cis women. The current recommendation is a mammogram every 2 years from age 50-74. Some guidelines (such as those by RHO and UCSF) specify to only start once the patient has been on feminizing hormone therapy for > 5 years total (up to 10 years according to UCSF), whereas others do not specify a minimum hormone duration use. Note that the presence of breast implants generally necessitates diagnostic mammography rather than routine screening mammography (RHO)

Subject: Information
General Patient Text: If you have not had top surgery to remove breast tissue in its entirety (also known as a mastectomy), you need a mammogram every 2 years from age 50 to 74. You still need mammograms even if you have had a breast reduction (and not a mastectomy). If you have had a mastectomy, discuss whether you need regular chest exams with your primary care provider; it is generally not the case.
Health Provider Text: Trans men and people on the transmasculine spectrum who have not had a bilateral mastectomy should undergo breast cancer screening, as per the current guidelines for cis women. The current recommendation for cis women is a mammogram every 2 years from age 50-74. There is currently no reliable evidence on screening for trans men and people on the transmasculine spectrum patients who have had a mastectomy; consider discussing the unknown risks associated with residual breast tissue, as well as the possible technical limitations of mammography (UCSF). Consider continuing regular monitoring for breast cancer even after mastectomy, as mastectomies usually do not remove breast tissue in its entirety; the Endocrine Society suggests conducting sub- and periareolar annual breast examinations if the patient has undergone a mastectomy, whereas UCSF cautions against it (not evidence-based).

Subject: Tips and Resources
General Patient Text: n/a
Health Provider Text: Be mindful of the language you use when referring to traditionally gendered body parts, as certain words may make patients feel uncomfortable — consider following the patients lead with regards to terminology (e.g. some trans men may prefer to refer to their breasts as their “chest”). Note that mastectomy typically does not involve the removal of all breast tissue, and that some may still remain in place, meaning that patients could still be at risk of breast cancer (TransCare BC). If an abnormality is noted on the exam of a trans man who had a mastectomy, ultrasound +/- MRI is indicated as mammography is technically difficult or may be impossible (RHO). Overview of breast cancer screening for trans men in Canada; Reference: https://www.cancer.ca/en/prevention-and-screening/reduce-cancer-risk/find-cancer-early/screening-in-lgbtq-communities/trans-men-and-chest-cancer-screening/?region=on, RHO guidelines; Reference: https://www.rainbowhealthontario.ca/wp-content/uploads/woocommerce_uploads/2019/12/Guidelines-FINAL-Dec-2019-iw2oti.pdf, UCSF Transcare guidelines; Reference: https://transcare.ucsf.edu/sites/transcare.ucsf.edu/files/Transgender-PGACG-6-17-16.pdf, Endocrine Society guidelines; Reference: https://academic.oup.com/jcem/article/102/11/3869/4157558

Subject: Prevent falls
General Patient Text: Bathroom: Make sure you have non slip surfaces or mats Grab bars, bath seat Raised toilet Make sure path is clear from bedroom to bathroom Home: Get rid of loose rugs or make non-slip Have good lighting and night lights Be active: Tai chi,walking, exercise classes etc Medications: Discuss with your provider if your medications can cause falls more; Reference: https://www.canada.ca/content/dam/phac-aspc/migration/phac-aspc/seniors-aines/alt-formats/pdf/publications/public/injury-blessure/prevent-eviter/prevent-eviter-e.pdf

Subject: Blood pressure
General Patient Text: During your visit to the doctor, ask for a measurement of your blood pressure. A normal blood pressure is under 140/90 mmHg or lower for some people . The target blood pressure depends on factors like age and health conditions, and where readings are being taken. If you have diabetes, kidney disease or other health conditions, speak to your health care professional about your target blood pressure. How to appropriately measure your blood pressure at home; Reference: https://hypertension.ca/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/BPM-Postcard-Front.jpg, Understanding and Managing Your Blood Pressure; Reference: https://guidelines.hypertension.ca/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/HTC_Brochure_UnderstandingBP_2018_R3.pdf
Health Provider Text: CTFPHC recommends blood pressure measurement at all appropriate primary care visits.2012 Guideline; Reference: https://canadiantaskforce.ca/guidelines/published-guidelines/hypertension/ (Strong recommendation; moderate quality evidence) Hypertension Canada guideline summary 2022; Reference: https://hypertension.ca/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/2020-22-HT-Guidelines-E-WEB_v3b.pdf, If the mean blood pressure measured in office As per recommended technique; Reference: https://guidelines.hypertension.ca/diagnosis-assessment/measuring-blood-pressure/, is high during one visit, a history and physical examination should be performed and, if clinically indicated, diagnostic tests to search for target organ damage should be arranged within 2 visits. Routine Lab Testing Recommended: urinalysis, blood chemistry (potassium, sodium and creatinine), fasting blood glucose and/or glycated hemoglobin (A1C), serum total cholesterol, LDL, HDL, non-HDL, triglycerides (fasting or non-fasting) and a standard 12-lead ECG. Global cardiovascular risk assessment should be done using risks calculators: Framingham only validated between age 30 and 74 risk calculator with happy faces; Reference: https://cvdcalculator.com/, more risk calculators; Reference: https://ccs.ca/calculators-and-forms/

Subject: Recommendations
General Patient Text: n/a
Health Provider Text: Recommend the app CanImmunize; Reference: https://www.canimmunize.ca/en/home {{AGE 18 and above (ALL ADULTS)}} The following schedule assumes the patient has been vaccinated in childhood (<Td>) (Tetanus-diphtheria) every 10 years (<Tdap>)(Tetanus,diphtheria, acellular pertussis or whooping cough): once in your lifetime (<Measles Mumps Rubella>):it is advised that most adults should have 2 doses of this vaccine (<HPV>): recommended for all females and males from ages 9 to 26. The vaccine is also safe over age 26. more; Reference: https://www.reframehealthlab.com/should-you-get-the-hpv-vaccine/ (<Influenza>): is recommended for all adults. For high risk groups see CanImmunize app (<Pneumococcal, varicella, meningococcal are recommended for some high risk groups>) seeCANImmunize app {{AGE 50+}} NACI recommends offering a Shingles vaccine starting at 50, Shingrix preferred, but in most provinces the patient will need to pay for this in this age group. NACI 2018; Reference: https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/reports-publications/canada-communicable-disease-report-ccdr/monthly-issue/2018-44/issue-9-september-6-2018/article-6-2018-naci-update-herpes-zoster-vaccines.html {{AGE 60+}} Shingles vaccine if not already received , see info above. Check if covered in your province. RSV: Arexvy is a new vaccine for RSV approved by Health Canada but no NACI recommendation is available. See your province's recommendation {{AGE 65+}} (<Shingles vaccine>) if not already given. Yukon and Ontario cover Shingrix from 65-70. For other provinces Zostavax may be covered , check your provincial schedule (<Pneumococcal>) PNEU-P-23 advised for all immunocompetent, repeat once in 5 years only if low immunity. Prevnar 20 advised as a better vaccine by NACI, not covered in most provinces (< Influenza>) yearly (<RSV>): Arexvy is a new vaccine for RSV approved by Health Canada but no NACI recommendation is available. See your province's recommendation. SOURCE: NACI; Reference: https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/immunization/national-advisory-committee-on-immunization-naci.html

Subject: Shingles vaccine
General Patient Text: Shingles is a disease that can cause permanent pain and eye problems. There are 2 vaccines against shingles: Shingrix and Zostavax. These vaccines are recommended starting at 50 years old but most provinces pay for them only at later ages. Discuss this with your health care provider. Studies show that Shingrix is more effective. 2 provinces cover Shingrix currently: Yukon and Ontario for patients aged 65 to 70. Check with your health care provider which vaccine is covered in your province and when . It is important to get vaccinated to prevent complications
Health Provider Text: n/a

Subject: Lung Cancer screening
General Patient Text: n/a
Health Provider Text: The CTFPHC (2016); Reference: https://canadiantaskforce.ca/guidelines/published-guidelines/lung-cancer/, recommends a Low dose CT (LDCT) for adults aged 55-74 years, with at least a 30 pack-year smoking history who currently smoke or quit less than 15 years ago. They recommend annual screening with LDCT up to three consecutive time. (Weak recommendation; low quality evidence) For all other adults, regardless of age, smoking history or other risk factors, they do recommend not screening for lung cancer with LDCT. Subject: Sexual health
General Patient Text: If you are on testosterone and have not had a hysterectomy (removal of the uterus), you need to use reliable form of birth control if there is a risk pregnancy based on your sexual practices, as testosterone can cause birth defects. If you are trying to or could become pregnant (based on your sexual practices), discuss this with your primary care provider, as taking a folic acid vitamin is important Condoms are recommended for anal sex. HIV testing is recommended for all Canadians at least once PHAC guidelines; Reference: https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/hiv-aids/hiv-screening-testing-guide.html, Depending on your sexual practices and history, screening for sexually transmitted infections and HIV may be recommended at different times. Discuss any concerns you may have with your primary care provider. If you have been the receptive partner during anal sex (“bottom”), your primary care provider may recommend regular anal Pap tests. RHO guidelines; Reference: https://www.rainbowhealthontario.ca/wp-content/uploads/woocommerce_uploads/2019/12/Guidelines-FINAL-Dec-2019-iw2oti.pdf, UCSF Transcare guidelines; Reference: https://transcare.ucsf.edu/sites/transcare.ucsf.edu/files/Transgender-PGACG-6-17-16.pdf
Health Provider Text: Those on testosterone who have not undergone hysterectomy need reliable birth control if pregnancy is a risk based on sexual activity, as testosterone is a teratogen (RHO). If pregnancy is possible based on sexual activity, follow the same folic acid recommendations as for cis women. Condoms are recommended for anal sex. Emphasize adequate provision of lubricants for trans women and trans men who have sex with men. Screen all Canadians for HIV at least once as per PHAC guidelines; Reference: https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/hiv-aids/hiv-screening-testing-guide.html, Screen for STIs based on behavioural history and sexual practices. Consider anal Pap tests every 2-3 years (or yearly in those who are HIV+) for those who have a history of receptive anal sex (RHO). In the LGBTQ+ community, the terms “bottom” and “top” are often used to describe the receptive and penetrative partners during sexual activity, respectively. The term “versatile” is used to describe someone who may alternate between these roles. Subject: Cervical Cancer
General Patient Text: Most trans women and non-binary people on the transfeminine spectrum do not need any cervical cancer screening, regardless of whether or not they have had a vaginoplasty. In the very rare instance where you would have had a cervix created during vaginoplasty, discuss the need for Pap tests with your primary care provider. If you have had a vaginoplasty, your primary care provider may suggest yearly visual examination with a speculum. Overview of cervical cancer screening for trans women in Canada; Reference: https://www.cancer.ca/en/prevention-and-screening/reduce-cancer-risk/find-cancer-early/screening-in-lgbtq-communities/trans-women-and-cervical-cancer-screening/?region=on, RHO guidelines; Reference: https://www.rainbowhealthontario.ca/wp-content/uploads/woocommerce_uploads/2019/12/Guidelines-FINAL-Dec-2019-iw2oti.pdf, UCSF Transcare guidelines; Reference: https://transcare.ucsf.edu/guidelines/cervical-cancer, Endocrine Society guidelines; Reference: https://academic.oup.com/jcem/article/102/11/3869/4157558 (Can be the same suggestions as for cisgender patients)
Health Provider Text: Trans women and people on the transfeminine spectrum generally do not need any cervical cancer screening as vaginoplasty does not usually entail creation of a neocervix. Neovagina vault testing is not recommended. In the very rare instances where a neocervix may have been created during vaginoplasty (such as from the skin of the glans penis), consider following the current cervical cancer screening guidelines for cis women (ACOG) (Pap tests are recommended every 3 years from age 21 to 69 if the person has ever been sexually active). Consider annual neovaginal speculum examination to visually detect any abnormalities (including malignancy) for those who have undergone vaginoplasty (RHO). Neovaginas may have a more posterior orientation than those of cis women, and using an anoscope rather than a speculum may be more appropriate for examination (UCSF). Overview of cervical cancer screening for trans women in Canada; Reference: https://www.cancer.ca/en/prevention-and-screening/reduce-cancer-risk/find-cancer-early/screening-in-lgbtq-communities/trans-women-and-cervical-cancer-screening/?region=on, Tips for physical examination of trans patients; Reference: https://transcare.ucsf.edu/guidelines/physical-examination, RHO guidelines; Reference: https://www.rainbowhealthontario.ca/wp-content/uploads/woocommerce_uploads/2019/12/Guidelines-FINAL-Dec-2019-iw2oti.pdf, UCSF Transcare guidelines; Reference: https://transcare.ucsf.edu/guidelines/cervical-cancer, Endocrine Society guidelines; Reference: https://academic.oup.com/jcem/article/102/11/3869/4157558

Subject: Stop Skin Cancer
General Patient Text: Wear protective clothing Limit time in the sun (worst time: between 10 am and 3 pm) Wear sunscreen (minimum SPF 30) Avoid tanning booth and sun beds; Reference: https://www.canada.ca/en/health-canada/services/sun-safety/tanning-beds-lamps.html, More info; Reference: https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/sun-safety/skin-cancer.html
Health Provider Text: To prevent Melanoma: Decrease exposure to sun with:protective clothing, sunscreen min SPF 30 CTFPHC appraised guideline 2014;Reference: https://canadiantaskforce.ca/guidelines/appraised-guidelines/melanoma/, Clinical assessment of future risk of melanoma take into account: - person’s age and sex - history of previous melanoma or non-melanoma skin cancer - family history of melanoma - number of naevi (common and atypical) - skin and hair pigmentation - response to sun exposure - evidence of actinic skin damage

Subject: Screening for impaired vision
General Patient Text: n/a
Health Provider Text: CTFPHC does not recommend screening for impaired vision in community dwelling adults 65 and over who do not have risk factors. CTFPHC 2018; Reference: https://canadiantaskforce.ca/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/CTFPHC_Impaired-Vision_Clinican-FAQ_Final.pdf, Canadian Ophthalmology Society 2007 consensus only recommendation: If high risk more frequent screening advised than below. High risk: African American, high myopia,diabetes or hypertension. 18-40 every 10 years 41-55 every 5 years 56-64 every 3 years 65 and above every year Current guideline under review; Reference: https://c2-preview.prosites.com/187380/wy/docs/COSVisionScreeningCPGEng_Feb07.pdf

Subject: Discuss with your primary care provider or see an optometrist
General Patient Text: Some people have a higher risk of vision problems: for example people of african-american origin and those with diabetes or hypertension . Discuss with your primary care provider if you need an eye exam or see an optometrist.

Subject: Get your blood pressure checked
General Patient Text: During your visit with your health care provider, ask for a measurement of your blood pressure. A normal blood pressure is under 140/90 mmHg or lower for some people . The target blood pressure depends on factors like age and health conditions, and where readings are being taken. If you have diabetes, kidney disease or other health conditions, speak to your health care professional about your target blood pressure. How to appropriately measure your blood pressure at home; Reference: https://hypertension.ca/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/BPM-Postcard-Front.jpg, Understanding and Managing Your Blood Pressure; Reference: https://guidelines.hypertension.ca/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/HTC_Brochure_UnderstandingBP_2018_R3.pdf
Health Provider Text: n/a

Subject: Guidelines
General Patient Text: n/a
Health Provider Text: CTFPHC recommends blood pressure measurement at all appropriate primary care visits. 2012 Guideline; Reference: https://canadiantaskforce.ca/guidelines/published-guidelines/hypertension/ (Strong recommendation; moderate quality evidence) Hypertension Canada guideline summary 2022; Reference: https://hypertension.ca/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/2020-22-HT-Guidelines-E-WEB_v3b.pdf, If the mean blood pressure measured in office As per recommended technique; Reference: https://guidelines.hypertension.ca/diagnosis-assessment/measuring-blood-pressure/, is high during one visit, a history and physical examination should be performed and, if clinically indicated, diagnostic tests to search for target organ damage should be arranged within 2 visits. Routine Lab Testing Recommended: urinalysis, blood chemistry (potassium, sodium and creatinine), fasting blood glucose and/or glycated hemoglobin (A1C), serum total cholesterol, LDL, HDL, non-HDL, triglycerides (fasting or non-fasting) and a standard 12-lead ECG. Global cardiovascular risk assessment should be done using risks calculators: Framingham only validated between age 30 and 74 Risk calculator with happy faces; Reference: https://cvdcalculator.com/, More risk calculators; Reference: https://ccs.ca/calculators-and-forms/
